turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments next in 1439, Hughes against Oklahoma.
Mr. Helton you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

This case is before you on appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of the State of Oklahoma in which the appellant was convicted of violating the following section of the Oklahoma Wildlife Code, specifically Section 4-115 (B) which provides in pertinent part as follows.

No person may transport or ship minnows for sale outside the state, which were seined or procured from the waters of this state except that; First; nothing contained herein shall prohibit any person from leaving the state possessing three dozen or less minnows.
Number two; nothing contained herein shall prohibit sale and shipment of minnows raised in a regularly licensed commercial minnow hatchery.
It is my position here in support of the proposition that the subject law is repugnant to the Commerce Clause of the United States.
Primarily, if it pleased the Court, based upon the decision of this Court of this past term in City of Philadelphia versus New Jersey --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Helton, I take it you are relying solely on the Commerce Clause?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, no other.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: You are not relying on the Privileges and Immunities Clause or anything else.
Just --

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: You put your case in the Commerce Clause?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Yes sir.
No other constitutional ground do I position at all.

That is to say that in as much as this law is 100% on its face blocked or curtained against interstate commerce, that it constitutes therefore that discriminatory nature, that disruption of the right to engage in interstate commerce by the other states and their citizens, particularly within the rule of this Court in the City of Philadelphia versus New Jersey, wherein Mr. Justice Stewart writing for your Court, said that; whenever the discrimination reached certain -- when it was that degree of discrimination, that it just constitutes a barrier of curtained interstate commerce, it’s unnecessary, it's immaterial to determine whether or not the state in enacting its law properly exercised its police power.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if Oklahoma passed a statute that had as its preamble or recital that the supply of buffalo if they have any or elk if they have any being limited, there could only be one taken by any person within a certain limited season and none could be taken outside of the State?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Alright sir.
And sir, Oklahoma did that in its conservation law in Section 116-A, the very following section that follows this section and I think that's a perfectly valid and legitimate law.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Fine.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: The difference sir in this case and the supposed case that you gave me is the party here complaining is not the party with the right of the access.
So in this case, Fred Shellkey (ph) is the man who took the minnows from the water of the State.
Mr. Hughes bought the minnows from Mr. Shellkey under this law.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But under this particular statute that before us now there is no prohibition against his buying, but there is a prohibition against his taking them out of the state, is there not?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: That is right sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How do you distinguish that from taking elk out of the states?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: The difference between the right to take in my judgment is the State very likely in fact I think without question, the State has and is properly exercising its police power when it controls the access to its wildlife as distinguished from controlling the right to, that is prohibiting the right to transport.
When at the same time they never prohibited, they never in any manner prohibited and attempted to control a disposition of it, the commerce in it from their license taker to the next party.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well so that, under the law you may commercialize with -- was natural minnows as long as you transport and sell them inside the State.
You can take natural minnows and sell them within the State of Oklahoma?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: In my -- I don't think there is any question about -- you are asking about the right of Oklahoma to limit that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, I am asking if I'm a dealer in minnows, I can buy natural minnows or I can go seine them myself and sell them to anybody I want to inside the state?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: You are right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And transport them anywhere I want to inside the State for sale?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But I can't transport them across the boundary for sale?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Or he can destroy them if you chooses, burn them up?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: I am sorry sir.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I say or he can destroy them if he chooses or burn them up as long as he does it within the state of Oklahoma?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: That would be right.
What I really, what I think that would help us is to understand that this overall conversation code of Oklahoma divides the commerce into two steps.
There is a division in the commerce and the first step with the commerce is from the water to the licensed, the party authorized to take them out of the water.
That's step number one, our commerce and if the court pleas that's internal commerce.
What Texas people or Texas as a (Inaudible) would have any interest in that, they would have none whatever.

But now there is a second step in the commerce and that second step is when the authorized taker sells and disposes and Oklahoma, and at that point because sir, because Oklahoma never put any kind of restriction on his right to -- the second step of that commerce is 100% unregulated by Oklahoma.
Oklahoma has not even enacted anything other than this one section, that deals with that second step of commerce.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But that regulates, doesn't it, that one section that you just referred to?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: It does sir, but and I don't disagree with it.

The very object of it though is to prevent the exportation, but the very object of it at that point since Oklahoma never by any other law limited that second step in any manner, never controlled it in any manner.
At that point, it had become inter-state commerce and at that point this law then has put the curtain that it cannot be.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You say then that Oklahoma could prohibit any sort of commercial dealing in natural minnows?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: I believe they can sir, provided, provided that they make the requisite necessary finding that's the basis of their exercising their police power.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I thought the police power is always presumed to have been properly exercised unless your state --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: States very seldom --

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: I don't understand it.
It's always presumed.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, aren't all state laws presumed constitutional?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: I am aware of the utterances to that effect, but I also I am aware that wherever a law shows on its face for example and refutes that presumption, then the presumption is refused.
Now then, if I be wrong, if I'm wrong in my position that is if I'm wrong in my position that the real of City of Philadelphia didn't apply for this case for example.

If I'm wrong in that, which I strongly believe I am not, but if I'm wrong then the next question that our cases teaches and tell us is that in the event that a law enacted under the police power is going to interfere with inter-state commerce.
There is a question of whether or not it's, the question is then is it doing it incidentally.

In other words, though there be a valid exercise of the police power in connection with the operation of that valid exercise that is there an incidental effect upon inter-state commerce and what is law in that respect.

Well, one of the -- at that point, it has recently been determined by this Court that the burden shifts upon the state to justify its own use, I mean, its police power use and in its justification, it must among things, show that it could not use its police power in a different manner, thereby reducing the burdens upon inter-state commerce.
Now then in this case, if we agree that the object of this law, which I find nothing in this law that supports this object either expressly or inferentially, but the Oklahoma high court did.
It said the purpose was to prevent depletion of minnows by commercial exportation or importation.
Oklahoma did not, but could have put catch limits on its minnows.
Oklahoma could have, but did not make any control over how many minnows the dealers would have in possession at one time.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Could they put a limit on how many could be transported over the state line?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: They certainly could in my opinion, yes sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Haven't they done so indirectly here?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: No sir.
For the reason that - well the real object of the three dozen rules, we got a lake down there between Texas and Oklahoma.
The Red River runs through and that, the three dozen rule in my opinion had reference to that lake.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Texoma I assume it is called.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: The part of the lake --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The lake is is called Texoma.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Yes sir, that's the name of it Your honor, it sure is.
Now then --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But what was the purpose, what do you suggest was the purpose of the three dozen limit?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: To take care of lake Texoma.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: In other words, I'm a Texan and I --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is there anything in the statute about that?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Anything in the statute about that?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: No, sir, no.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What do you suggest on its face the three dozen limits implies or suggests?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Well, if the --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You want to hold down.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: There really isn't anything from the law that we could tell anything Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Isn't it the same kind of limitation that you put, that you can only take six trout or five pheasants or whatever?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Well, I feel this way that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Isn't it a conservation measure?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: I'm unable to read a conservation measure in the three dozen.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, isn't three dozen about what you might mean for a day of fishing, to catch whatever limits Oklahoma has.
Isn't there a reasonable possibility that there's a relationship?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Well, my trouble sir is I fish too much down there and I can understand the relationship of three dozen to us local boys that fish now --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You don't have –-

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Now that's not in this record and I understand that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You don't really need it --

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Well to me --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: More than three dozen in a day do you?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: It is impertinent sir.
I know there is no -- three dozen couldn't have anything to do with conservation of the minnows in Oklahoma or at least that's my opinion it being there.
It's not supported by the records, but that's – if I maybe indulged then I will say that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Helton I didn't understand, but I guess I'm just stupid, but what is the reference to lake Texoma?
Why would this problem --

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Alright sir.
On Red River sir, there's a lake that dammed up that river and thus the water that rivers in both states.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: So consequently, I think the legislature had in mind, if a Texas fisherman came over into Oklahoma to buy him some minnows and does go back on the Texas side of the lake to fish without this exception, he can be a violator of this law.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, why don't you make him fish on the Oklahoma side of the lake you know that.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Oh that's terrific.
I hadn't thought about that; that would be one effect of it.
You make him fish for he didn't want a fish.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Of course, if they want to make him fish on the Oklahoma side of the lake they would have no exception at all?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: If I listen to you sir, you're meaning to infer that -- if they wanted to leave the three dozen exception acts --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: They'd force him to fish.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: The effect would be the Texan people fish on the Oklahoma side.
Yes sir, I think that would be right.

Now then -- I naturally, there is, after we read the residue of this law that is other than this Section 4-115 (A) or 115 (B), other than that one law, there isn't a single law in this code that directs itself toward any kind of general welfare protection, that is protection of Oklahoma minnows.

It's totally barren of any kind of the law, because it's totally barren of any kind of law, it automatically, the only thing you can decide is that they wanted to give the (Inaudible) an economic benefit that it's a discriminatory law that discriminated in favor of the (Inaudible) business.
The other thing about the law that's to foster and carry out and further the general welfare of power of the people of Oklahoma.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Helton, could I ask you one question before you sit down.
Do you think it would be necessary if we were to rule in your favor for us to expressly overrule the case of Geer against Connecticut?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Well, sir, I -- no sir I'm really, yes and no, if I may.
I'll answer yes part first and then no part second.
First sir, the statue in the Geer case is basically and fundamentally different in this Oklahoma Statute.
The difference is this.
Geer directed the prohibition to the very act of taking, the word Geer statue says it is hereby prohibited for anyone to kill our wild life and remove them from the state.
Now I haven't quoted it to you verbatim, but I haven't deviated that.
Now this law, unlike Geer isn't directed to the taker.
The actual statutes aren't connected with the power or the access to take.
That distinguishes Geer --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But it makes the Oklahoma Statute narrower than the one in here, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Sir I am sorry.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Doesn't it make the Oklahoma Statute narrower than the one in Geer?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Narrower?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Because Oklahoma Statute regulates less conduct than the Connecticut Statute did in Geer?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Well sir to me the Geer statute, the emphasis is on the initial right to take.
The Oklahoma Statute doesn't focus its emphasis there.
It focuses trying to enforce something that's not visible in the law.

Now then thus, now then I said that yes and then no, now then the other part, the other side of the coin is to me this Court in the last term, in the last recent terms, in Baldwin versus Montana and all the cases you've stated there, limited to interstate commerce only.
I think that you have the -- I think you have more or less terminated now the ownership doctrine.
I am not talking about that you've terminated the power of the states under the police power.
You said the majority opinion relative to the ownership of wild game in the states was error.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Bruce?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice may it please the Court.
In order to focus upon Oklahoma's argument before this Court, I feel it incumbent upon me to bring to the Court's attention the posture of the appellant's argument in the court's decision below.
The posture of the argument below are the appellant was in the form of distinguishing Geer versus Connecticut from the case of Foster-Fountain Packing Company versus Haydel.
Now as this Court is aware the Geer decision involved wildlife.
The statute there prohibited the transport of that wildlife across the state line.

In Foster-Fountain Packing Company versus Haydel, this Court looked at the underlying fact situation involved in that case where the Louisiana Statute in the name of conservation prohibited the exportation of shrimp in which the hose and heads had not been removed, thereby requiring their removal in the home state of Louisiana.
This Court held in that case that the purpose and effect of that statute was economic protectionism for Louisiana residents.
That is, that statute favored Louisiana simply because by the very nature of the statute, the packing was required to be done in Louisiana to the exclusion of other states.

Now in the lower court as I mentioned, the appellant distinguished Geer versus Connecticut from Foster-Fountain Packing Company versus Haydel and relied up on the Foster case stating that it was applicable to this case.
The posture, however on appeal by the appellant here is that as I read his brief that Geer versus Connecticut is no longer viable when subjected to a Commerce Clause tag.
It's the view of Oklahoma that the concept in Geer is still viable today.
The concept of the state's interest, the state's interest in controlling its wildlife is as much as alive today as it was in the time when Geer versus Connecticut was rendered.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: What in your opinion Mr. Attorney General is the justification for the Oklahoma statute?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: As a conservation measure, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, do you agree with counsel on the other side that a Texas resident could go into Oklahoma and buy minnows and burn them up in front of the commercial establishment from which he bought them?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: I would agree if there is no statutory prohibition.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: That there's no wildlife conservation.

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: No, sir, the statute does not address that, that possibility notion.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, if that's a possibility, why they would be characterized as a conservation measure?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Well, as argued by the appellant below in which the state concedes the only viable commercial use for minnows is as bait for other fish.
It serves no other purpose as far as man is concerned in his commercial interest.

Of course the state maintains that minnows also serve other important functions of course as a natural food supply for game fish and that the balance of the – for the maintaining of the balance of the minnow population in the natural streams.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: For ducks and birds and a lot of others too, don't they--?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- live off of minnows.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Isn't that interest served just as much on the Texas side, of the lake that straddles the state boundary?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Are you speaking of Lake Texoma Mr. Justice Blackmun?

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Whatever the lake is?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Yes, I think that interest would serve Texas as well as Oklahoma.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Wouldn't it serve just as much on a lake ten miles inside Texas as Oklahoma lake?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: I am not sure I understand your question sir.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, suppose that Mr. Hughes here took his minnows and sold them to Texas fishermen on a lake ten miles inside the Texas boundary, isn't that natural preservation purpose just as well served there, or are you restricting it entirely to Oklahoma nature?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Well, I would concede that certainly that would serve Texas interests, but such wholesale exploitation of minnows, natural minnows in Oklahoma streams, if Oklahoma permitted the export, it would require Oklahoma to not only keep track of what's happening, but to make sure that additional minnows were added to make up for those which were exported.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: But at the same time though, I could go into Oklahoma and buy them and bring them up.

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: And there is no statute that would prevent me from doing so?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Maybe the next legislature counsel may take that into account and make a standard prohibition?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Well sir, we've never had that type of problem in Oklahoma?[Laughter]

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I doubt if you will either.

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Now one another case citied by the appellant the City of Philadelphia versus New Jersey of course a recent case by this Court regarding a dispute between New Jersey and other states regarding the land -- for use of landfill sites.

In my brief, I distinguish that case as I did other cases in that, in that case it involved a discrimination provision, in other words the State of New Jersey discriminated against out of state citizens as opposed to citizens of its own state.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Also the subject of a commerce wasn't wildlife?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The Geer case didn't have anything to do with that case?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Yes sir and as I pointed out in my brief or hopefully I pointed out in my brief that wildlife is a unique area of law, and that the state has special interest in preserving the wildlife.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you -- do you think in serving that in you can permit commercialization with the same natural minnows within the state, but prevent their export?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Just as a way of limiting the take?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: A way of conservation yes Mr. Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Even though there are no limits on the amount or number of minnows that your own people can take?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: I might say that I believe other states do use the possession limit as a means of protecting their interest as an advice to --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Anybody, any out of staters who come to Oklahoma, they are free to buy minnows and use them in Oklahoma waters.

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Yes Mr. Justice White they are.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Your Oklahoma supply people are -- then have -- they have the exclusive on the sale of naturally seined minnows?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Well, they are licensed by the state, yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, there is no prohibition against buying minnows in Texas and bringing them into Oklahoma and using them as a bait, is there?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There is a prohibition on buying Oklahoma minnows?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Well, that's the focus of our statute in issue here.
There isn't an Oklahoma provision regarding an import license.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now we got -- what's there about that?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: But that's not the focus of the inquiry here.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But what about it then?
Can I bring minnows from out of the state and use them in the Oklahoma waters?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: The statute provides a procedure for that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: For the licensing?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You don't object to commercial raising of minnows and taking them?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Commercial hatchery of minnows, no Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You don't object to people taking them and seining them either do you as such?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Because this man here was a professional (Inaudible).
That was his business of seining wild minnows.

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So If you are allowed that unlimited, how are you preserving wildlife or protecting wildlife –

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: The very –

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- the unlimited.

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Alright sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The taking is unlimited, right?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And sold it off.

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: As to the number taken, no sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Mr. Justice Marshall in response to your inquiry, the -- it's true that Oklahoma has no numerical limits on the actual taking of minnows from its natural streams.

There is really no need for that in light of the exportation law that is since as appellant and appellee both agree that the only commercial interest in minnows is as bait, that's the sole commercial interest of minnows.
Then those that are seined from Oklahoma streams are returned to Oklahoma streams in the form of bait.
So it does -- there is really no need for --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Supposed they were returned to the streams in a state above Oklahoma, wouldn't they in turn return to Oklahoma?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Well, if it adjoined, if the stream ran into Oklahoma, yes sir, conceivably they would.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So that's not the only point.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Bruce when they returned to the streams as bait, their life expectancy isn't very long.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Stevens I won't debate.
I am not a fisherman unlike Mr. Helton I'm not a --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The minnow's life expectancy isn't the longest anyhow?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would you take the position that Oklahoma could have a statute that said that any fish caught in Oklahoma shall be consumed in Oklahoma, isn't that what the statute, with respect to one time?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So they could say any fish caught here have to be consumed, cannot be shipped out of state?
That's the same issue, isn't it?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Just like Geer?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We are not – we were discussing in response to some questions the fact there is no limit on how much you can – what quantity of natural minnows can be seined within the state, but the only purpose, the rational purpose of seining within the state would be for a dealer to sell them under that three dozen limit to other fishermen is that not so?
You wouldn't go about seining fish just for the--?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: For recreational purposes, no Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- they're not edible in that sense, and will be pretty expensive fertilizer, you would only be seining them to probably to sell them three dozen at a time to fishermen?

turn.speaker: bill_j_bruce
turn.label: Mr. Bill J. Bruce
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor.
The statutory scheme is self executing so to speak that the natural and practical commercial object of minnows serves as a natural limitation.
If the Oklahoma bars the exportation, then they would be returned to Oklahoma streams in the form of bait.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you any further, Mr. Helton?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Your Honor, I'm just -- in answer to Mr. Justice White's question to counsel in Section 4-1159(A) it provides, “No person may ship or transport minnows for sale into this state from an outside source without having first procured a license for such from the Director.
So if you come to Oklahoma fishing from your native state Colorado, don't bring any minnows.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Without a license.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: And you can't get one, now let's talk about minnow dealer license and you can't get a minnow dealer's license.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They just --

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: -- unless you are a resident of Oklahoma.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: So I am pointing out to you that nobody can come into Oklahoma to fish and bring their minnows into Oklahoma.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And so no out of state minnow dealer, fellows who would like to sell you the fishing equipment can send you any minnows from outside the state for two reasons.
One, you can't get any Oklahoma minnows--

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: And then of course for an outsider that wanted to bring minnows into Oklahoma --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Can't get the license.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: -- to feed the fish in Oklahoma, couldn't do it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well could you read that language again Mr. Helton.
I wasn't sure from its literal language that it applied to someone who wasn't trying to sell them in Oklahoma?

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: “No person may ship or transport minnows for sale” you were right sir, yes sir I am sorry sir you can do it

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I may tempt to bring my minnows into Oklahoma.

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Yes sir, okay you are right Mr. Justice --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: As long as he goes into --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: That's a great relief to Mr. Justice White.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: robert_m_helton
turn.label: Mr. Robert M. Helton
turn.text: Yeah.
Thank you gentlemen.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
